job_title: Assistant Director of Athletic Operations in Tulsa, OK

review_title: I worked as a Math tutor when I was a student
pros: Friendly workplace, everyone is kind. They have well-structured departments for leadership and have open communication. There were many jobs available within the university. It was not bureaucratic to find a job
cons: Since this was a work-study position, pay was low. Hopefully, in the future pay will increase for some positions available for students within the university

review_title: Good People, Not the Best Balance
pros: Awesome people, amazing leadership in my department.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth. Very few remote work opportunities.

pros: The employees outside of IT management are friendly and easy to work with.
cons: IT Management have an inflated sense of their own importance, a deep need for excessive attention and admiration, and a lack of empathy for others. Always looking for the next photo opportunity just to promote themselves. On a regular bases they threaten to fire you over anything just to make an example of you to others.

pros: Working in the Missions and Outreach Office has been one of the best experiences that I've had while being a student at ORU. You get hands-on experience in whichever corner of the office you work for, garnering the ability for hard and soft skills as well as networking opportunities.
cons: The Missions Office is based on a Work Study as a student, so the pay is minimum wage although you can make up to $3000 throughout the academic year.

job_title: Residence Hall Director in Tulsa, OK

review_title: Love the people, but disappointing pay and treatment
pros: The people I worked with were amazingly supportive and kind. I cherished most of my students and our interactions. The ability to talk about God openly was a huge advantage. My department head did ever he could to support me.
cons: The pay is really low, even for full time professors. They expect employees to work overtime without additional pay sometimes, which is unethical. Online instructors are expected to answer emails very promptly and grade quickly. If you don’t and you get a poor evaluation from a student, they may not renew your contract. The president runs the place like a church camp sometimes and has very little experience with higher education before he was hired. He got rid of many good professors that were not “yes men” and warned all who didn’t have PhDs that they would be replaced if they didn’t get the PhD ASAP. He would rather spend $$$ on faculty lunches and Christmas parties then use that money towards pay raises, then has the audacity to ask faculty for donations. The vast majority of advertising and funds is directed towards undergraduates and the poor grad students are left out many times. The grad scholarships are jokes. Housing is expensive not up to par except for maybe the new dorms. Grade inflation is a huge problem! Students feel entitled. Student support services caters to student athletes and the help they give is just executive function/homework helps without little help for students with LDs and EDs. Counselors on campus are few; there are long waits for appointments. There is a lot of turnover and position changes in auxiliary and lower level support staff, which makes communication between departments nightmarish, if existing at all.

pros: I worked for a great professor in the college of business.
cons: I loved my experience working there.

pros: The job is great to work at
cons: There are no cons for this job

review_title: ORU is a fantastic place to work and go to school!
pros: Boss and I clicked, can't find anything wrong. Loved the content and the students.
cons: I can't really find anything, other than the Biology dept. here is a little neglected. Please buy new lab equipment!

pros: Over all it was a excellent and learning experience and

pros: The program offers a great community to surround yourself with and has many great mentors to guide you
cons: It is a lot of work with little pay and we must pay for the taxes ourselves. There is a lot of nitpicky work that becomes aggravating after it piles up.

review_title: Not a good place for working
pros: People at ORU are very committed. Christians that love the students.
cons: Terrible self-serving presidential leadership. Everything started when president was given a 10-year contract and began making decisions that affected faculty and staff. Faculty lost tenure and pandemic made things worse when everybody had to accept salary cuts. Salaries were already low and then were reduced even more. Leadership prefers to spend money on unnecessary buildings and other non-critical items such as president's tv program, when there is lack of basic supplies and software and faculty struggle to get somebody to replace them when they get sick with COVID since university would not pay for substitutes. There is present toxic organizational culture that produce exhausted personnel that live under constant pressure. Not a good place for working.

pros: Offered flexible hours and payed for your tutor certification.

review_title: A wonderful clean environment in which to grow.
pros: Wonderful quality people to work with and management that cares.  The professors really care for their students and strive to help them with life decisions.  It's a nice campus with some architectually interesting buildings.  It tends to attract those willing to sign the honor codes, which makes for more quality employees and a nicer and cleaner environment.  They also offer college benefits... the percentage increases with years employed.  The University is quite the benefit to the city of Tulsa as well as the quality of student that they produce!
cons: Possibly working under someone who doesn't have the original mission at heart or has wrong motives but that could happen anywhere.  However, ORU has new management and many things have improved greatly and continue to improve!  They are working to bring salaries in line and upgrading equipment and refurbishing buildings and adding a new student center as well.

review_title: Good team with many opportunities for growth
job_title: Senior Server Administrator in Tulsa, OK
pros: There are a lot of knowledgeable IT professionals on the team. This is a private Christian University and the employees live by a 'lifestyle' code.  Not unlike the Ethics codes that have been adopted by most Fortune 100 companies, but there are some differences. They have a fairly modern IT department with opportunities to learn using most modern technologies.  VMware, Microsoft AD, a comprehensive and modern network (though not Cisco), various flavors of Oracle and Microsoft SQL, a lot of Linux, and a sophisticated Data Center.
cons: Salaries rarely change.  Income growth can only be achieved through an increase in skillsets and a move up in the organization.  It is sometimes difficult to make necessary improvements due to budget restraints.

review_title: Despite the problems, I love working here.
pros: Many faculty and staff have invested years of their lives into the university and believe strongly in its mission. Service to the students is our first priority. Recent significant pay raises have been given to the faculty,
cons: Many of the staff are seriously underpaid. Some departments are understaffed. The library is understaffed and underfunded. Many of the middle managers and administrators appear either powerless or unwilling to effect change. The new president does not have the necessary knowledge base to effectively do his job. There are long term money problems.

job_title: Held IV Different Positions While There in Tulsa, OK
pros: I was younger when I worked at ORU. I was in the admissions office and took on several roles including being a temporary Office Manager, but I enjoyed it very much for the most part.
cons: My only complaint would be that the manager of the department cried too easily and often. Personally, I believe that even when things are difficult, especially the manager should maintain some sort of control over ourselves. Another thing would be, the head counselor was always asking me to prepare long reports, but he always took full credit for it instead of me like it should have been.

pros: There is a fantastic sense of community among staff members. Those working at the university feel a deep sense of satisfaction knowing they are making a difference in the lives of students & are a part of a strong mission/vision.
cons: The higher levels of administration are not in touch with the needs of students or students/faculty/staff. They are out of touch & tend to make rash decisions at a moment's notice. There is a prevailing culture of fear among faculty & staff that they could be fired at any moment.

pros: In general, great students, & great opportunities to grow
cons: Top-heavy leadership, too many VP's & useless executive-level positions, political, spiritually manipulative at times, stuck in old ways, authoritarian professional environment, & discouraging to new methods/approaches.

review_title: Fear-Based Leadership, Unhealthy Place to Work
pros:
Great co-workers 
Christian atmosphere 
10 days of vacation (if you're allowed to take them)
cons:
Fear-based leadership 
Unhealthy strain on mental health due to unattainable goals 
Lack of feedback unless it's negative 
Denied vacation time and made to feel bad if you take sick time
Lots of overtime without pay
Time taken advantage of and not compensated for

review_title: Nice place to work, for some departments
pros: Teamwork.  Most care about the success of the university.
cons: Some departments are more stressful than others due to the leadership in those areas.  Many unexpected and unexplained "resignations" for a particular segment of the university, which has resulted in poor motivation.

review_title: I was a student worker, not salaried

cons: Some departments can be very clique-ish, and while I like the new administration, I believe that the way in which they let some people go was kind of cold and not very tactful.

pros: I really enjoy the job and what I do. The vision and mission of the university is great and something very inspiring to work for.
cons: The leadership at ORU is shoddy at best. I have seen and heard some very questionable things that makes me believe leadership uses the university as a personal platform for their own advantage.

pros: They empower student leaders and enable students to have extensive responsibility. Usually students who are leaders make a little more than the average student.
cons:
Poor communication at times between students and supervisors. I was discontinued a position because a change of supervisor and wasn't promised the position. It was incredibly
Inappropriate and unprofessional.

review_title: Little pay for lots of work

cons: Non-progressive academically. PhD and research required but class load and lack of funds make it difficult. Many of faculty has their degree from ORU or come from families in the Tulsa area. . Much nepotism and favoritism.

Strong morals and integrity and there is nothing I can say bad about ORU except they were good to me.
The system manager left ORU in short notice and I was chosen to pull daily DOS reports which was fun and challenging.
cons: I think the most difficult time for me was when it became my responsibility to merge positions into one fluent, efficient position so they could lay people off.

review_title: Great place to work! Marvelously innovative!
pros: Great technical support and positive atmosphere. Faculty and staff well supported by upper tier leaders.  Students from all over the world make it an interesting place to work.
cons: Rapid growth and lots of change make keeping up hard. Forward thinking leadership can require a lot of faculty but stretching is good for progress.

pros: The competence, integrity and vision of the staff and faculty have steered the University toward a vision of higher education that you can really get behind. Six years operating in the black with 8 years of student growth...amazing
cons: As with some big organizations there are some areas that aren't always instep with the best practices that are being implemented...it will get there eventually
